title: 4chan users embrace AI voice clone tool to generate celebrity hatespeech

last_post.content:
It's 2023. "Gosh, we didn't realize how people would misuse this" just isn't believable anymore.

Bare minimum, with any new tech:
1) How would a stalker use this?
2) What will 4chan do with this?

And don't release, not even as alpha or beta, before mitigating those risks.

https://www.theverge.com/2023/1/31/23579289/ai-voice-clone-deepfake-abuse-4chan-elevenlabs

#AIethics #ethNLP

@botwiki Can you also keep me in the loop, and encourage everyone who does this to post here?

https://forms.gle/WLBK1jaE2vaxW1U2A

And those on Twitter to retweet this?

https://twitter.com/tchambers/status/1621553445273767936

title: A New Drug Switched Off My Appetite. What’s Left?

last_post.content:
In my most recent column for WIRED I describe my experience with Mounjaro, a new drug for type 2 diabetics that deeply manipulates satiety, with a side effect of radical weight loss.

Fat is a vast subject involving economics, agriculture, race, gender, sexuality, cultural norms, psychology, biology, even climate. In contrast I'm relating an individual, fragmentary experience, in a state of confusion, at a moment of vulnerability. I'm sure it will go great.

https://www.wired.com/story/new-drug-switched-off-appetite-mounjaro/

title: Journalistic Lessons for the Algorithmic Age – The Markup

last_post.content:
I’m sad to announce that I am leaving @themarkup to pursue other projects, which I will announce soon.

It was an honor and a privilege to found @themarkup five years ago to create an investigative newsroom that integrated engineers and journalists. We showed the world what journalism could be: math literate, computationally superpowered, and human-centered.

On my departure, I thought I would reflect on the ten lessons I learned leading these investigations. https://themarkup.org/hello-world/2023/02/04/journalistic-lessons-for-the-algorithmic-age

"They understood that most websites lack tight latency budgeting, dedicated performance teams, hawkish management reviews, ship gates to prevent regressions, and end-to-end measurements of critical user journeys. They understood the only way to scale JS-driven frontends are massive investments in controlling complexity, but warned none of their customers."

"The Market for Lemons", excellent read: https://infrequently.org/2023/02/the-market-for-lemons/

#software #softwareDevelopment #complexity

Different every time. Excellent.
https://www.monkeon.co.uk/gifaanisqatsi/

title: Getty Images v. Stability AI - Complaint

last_post.content:
Getty Images claims in a new lawsuit against Stability AI that output images are showing derivations of their watermark and thus violating their trademark.¹ (h/t @copyrightlately). Tangentially, this reminds me of Nintendo's strategy to stop unauthorized Game Boy publishers. The hardware checked cartridges for that iconic scrolling Nintendo logo on boot, allowing them to sue unapproved game devs who used it.² (h/t @stacksmashing)

¹ https://copyrightlately.com/pdfviewer/getty-images-v-stability-ai-complaint/
² https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ix5yZm4fwFQ

title:
Russia's Role in the Far-Right Truck Convoy
							| The Journal of Intelligence, Conflict, and Warfare

last_post.content: Ok, so now that I’ve had a moment to breathe, let me take a few minutes to dive into the study I just published about Russian involvement in the 2022 truck convoy in Canada. The study can be read in full here: https://journals.lib.sfu.ca/index.php/jicw/article/view/5101

Hey folks, TootSDK is now public! 🚀

TootSDK is a Swift package for creating apps that interact with Mastodon, Pleroma and other Fediverse APIs.

It handles the data model and network calls, with lovely async/await based calls.

The SDK is still young. There are plenty of API calls still to add. The foundations are strong, and TootSDK is very useful already.

Contributions and PRs are more than welcome!

Check out the repo here: https://github.com/tootsdk/tootsdk :mastodance: :apple:

#swift #iosdev #vapor #serversideswift #appkit #uikit #swiftui

title: INTRODUCTION TO PYTHON FOR HUMANISTS — Introduction to Python for Humanists

last_post.content: I am loving this super well-written Intro to Python for Humanists by W. J. B. Mattingly--it's wonderfully accessible to students just starting out and exploring NLP, and it's timely and wide-ranging in its examples: combining word embeddings via spaCy and gensim with topic modeling via nltk--and best of all it's really for hunanist approaches to word salads. Super happy with Mattingly's stuff. :-) https://python-textbook.pythonhumanities.com/intro.html

It's not as handy as Movetodon, but Twitter hasn't shut down Debirdify yet. Sync up your Twitter followers on Mastodon before the Twitter API gets locked down

https://debirdify.pruvisto.org/

title: GitHub - 11ty/eleventy-plugin-bundle: Little bundles of code, little bundles of joy.

last_post.content:
New plugin release: @11ty/eleventy-plugin-bundle

https://github.com/11ty/eleventy-plugin-bundle

Create minimal per-page or app-level bundles of CSS, JavaScript, or HTML to be included in your Eleventy project.

Makes it easy to implement Critical CSS, in-use-only JS bundles, SVG icon libraries, or secondary HTML content to load via XHR.

This brings some of the WebC Bundler Mode features to other template types: Nunjucks, Liquid, Handlebars, and 11ty.js—and we’ll circle back to use this in WebC moving forward!

Our paper 'The Epistemic and Pragmatic Function of Dichotomous Claims Based on Statistical Hypothesis Tests' is now in press in Theory & Psychology. https://psyarxiv.com/af9by/ I am very proud of this paper. I know we are arguing against the status quo. I think this contains the best arguments for the use of dichotomous interpretations of tests (e.g p<.05) in the literature (and stronger arguments than I have seen from anyone defending 'continuous' interpretations of tests.

title: Evidence for a core set of microbial lichen symbionts from a global survey of metagenomes

last_post.content: New #preprint alert! What are the core symbionts of lichens? TLDR: we analyzed >400 lichen metagenomes from around the world and found that 4 bacterial groups are as frequent in lichens as the alga, one of the two main partners in the symbiosis. 🧵 1/11 https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.02.02.524463v1

YouTube subcontractors have gone on strike, making it the first official strike in Google/Alphabet history: https://time.com/6252740/youtube-contractors-google-strike-union/

#union #unions #strike #google #tech #solidarity

@albertocairo
1/N thread - (writing a meaningful short answer required more time than a long one)

First principle for scientific papers: readability and explorability of data must have priority over aesthetic preferences. Graphic design should support the readability and clarity of the data rather than dominate it. #dataviz must aid the communication of unique, potentially complex findings among experts.

An example from: https://doi.org/10.2967/jnumed.120.245977 #PET #imaging #pulmonary #perfusion #HIV #lung

title: CSS Custom Highlight API: A First Look | CSS-Tricks

last_post.content:
Do you wish you could style arbitrary text ranges on the web without having to change the underlying DOM?

Well, with the CSS Custom Highlight API, you can! 🌟

check my article about it to learn more:
https://css-tricks.com/css-custom-highlight-api-early-look/

I’m also writing MDN docs for it. Coming soon…
https://github.com/mdn/content/pull/23907

Available in Chromium and Webkit (behind a flag).

title: The Cement Mixer Space Capsule of Winganon

last_post.content:
A cement truck crashed near Winganon, Oklahoma in the 1950s and the mixer was too heavy to move. It’s still there; locals have painted it to look like an abandoned NASA
capsule.

https://www.amusingplanet.com/2015/10/the-cement-mixer-space-capsule-of.html

I have just finished the processing for the revival of my old podcast searching site, PodSearch. I'm using the amazing Whisper speech-to-text engine to convert some of my favorite shows into easily searchable textual archives.

I've included The Talk Show, ATP, Upgrade, Cortex, Connected & Under the Radar.

PodSearch: https://podsearch.david-smith.org

Explanation: https://www.david-smith.org/blog/2023/02/02/podsearch-reborn/

title: Myspace loses all content uploaded before 2016

last_post.content:
Reminder that whatever you store on an internet site will one day vanish, even if it's stored on the largest and richest site in the world:

"Myspace, the once mighty social network, has lost every single piece of content uploaded to its site before 2016, including millions of songs, photos and videos with no other home on the internet."

https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/mar/18/myspace-loses-all-content-uploaded-before-2016

Please don't rely on internet services to exist forever, they will all disappear eventually.

Try to store copies of important stuff offline if you can. Music, video, photos etc can all be stored locally.

title: Elon Musk says Twitter will provide a free write-only API to bots providing 'good' content

last_post.content:
Such BS, do not fall for this. The fact that he can change the rules on a whim is enough of a reason to continue with your plans to migrate your bots away from Twitter's unstable platform.

https://techcrunch.com/2023/02/04/elon-musk-says-twitter-will-provide-a-free-write-only-api-to-bots-providing-good-content/

Probably best to just turn your bots off and not let this guy decide their fate.

title: Voices in the Code: Algorithms, People and Values

last_post.content:
New podcast!

Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University research director Katy Glenn Bass hosted a conversation based on themes from David G. Robinson’s first book, Voices in the Code, featuring Robinson, Deborah Raji and J. Nathan Matias.

The book bears insights on how algorithmic systems that are often heavily freighted with moral and political complexity can and should be developed with care to avoid excluding the voices of non-technical stakeholders.
https://techpolicy.press/voices-in-the-code-algorithms-people-and-values/

title: Sam Harris | #310 - Social Media & Public Trust

last_post.content:
I went on the Sam Harris Podcast w/Bari Weiss & Michael Shellenberger - two journos who worked on the Twitter files - to talk ab social media & public trust. Some of the convo was ab findings- different interpretations of Files stories -but much was ab loss of trust in institutions. We talked ab “Russiagate”, the role of the govt (FBI & CDC talking to platforms?), the infamous 💻, & the need for transparency.

https://www.samharris.org/podcasts/making-sense-episodes/310-social-media-public-trust

Some users are so prolific and so high-quality uploaders that just visiting their "user uploads" page is an exquisite curation it itself.

Such it is with THE IBIS REBELLION, who has been scanning in and uploading discard pulp magazines with a nod to quality and evocation for years:

https://archive.org/details/@the_ibis_rebellion

A brief #introduction: I'm a data scientist w/ a math+stats background. I've been with the Wikimedia Foundation (the non-profit behind Wikipedia) for 7y+ and I've been managing since 2021

You may have read my guide on hiring: https://magazine.amstat.org/blog/2018/09/01/hiring-a-data-scientist/

I’ve written about my journey as an individual contributor (back in 2017) on my blog: https://mpopov.com/blog/2017/09/21/the-journey-so-far/

I've authored a few R packages, most notably WikidataQueryServiceR

You can learn about my team and what we do at https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Product_Analytics
